revision.text:
{{for|the American football player and actor|Mike Henry (American football)}} {{Infobox person | name = Mike Henry | image = Mike Henry Actor 01.jpg | caption = Mike Henry in the studio 2018 | birth_name = Michael Henry | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1965|11|07}} | birth_place = [[Pontiac, Michigan]], U.S. | education = [[Collegiate School (Richmond, Virginia)|Collegiate School]]
[[Washington and Lee University]] | occupation = Voice actor, writer, producer, comedian | years_active = 1989–present | children = 2 | website = [https://www.mikehenry.co www.mikehenry.co] }} '''Michael "Mike" Henry''' (born November 7, 1965) is an American voice actor, writer, producer, and comedian. He is known for his work on the animated TV series ''[[Family Guy]]'' (1999–present), where he writes and produces episodes along with voicing [[Cleveland Brown]], [[Herbert (Family Guy)|Herbert]], [[List of Family Guy characters#Bruce|Bruce]], and [[List of Family Guy characters#Consuela|Consuela]]. Henry is also known for co-creating and starring in the spin-off, ''[[The Cleveland Show]]'' (2009–2013) and for his recurring role as Dann in the television series, ''[[The Orville]]''.{{Cite news|url=http://www.campustimes.org/2008/09/11/mike-henry-of-family-guy-talks-voices-gags-and-instinct/|title=Mike Henry of "Family Guy" talks voices, gags and instinct - Campus Times|date=2008-09-11|work=Campus Times|access-date=2018-05-01|language=en-US}}{{Citation|title=The Cleveland Show|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1195935/|others=Mike Henry, Sanaa Lathan, Kevin Michael Richardson|accessdate=2018-05-01}}{{Citation|title=Family Guy|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0182576/|others=Seth MacFarlane, Alex Borstein, Seth Green|accessdate=2018-05-01}}{{Citation|title="The Orville" Cupid's Dagger (TV Episode 2017)|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt6850956/fullcredits/|accessdate=2018-05-10}} ==Early life== Henry and his younger brother Patrick were born to artist parents and raised in [[Richmond, Virginia]]. His parents divorced when he was six years old and he was primarily raised by his mother. Although money was tight, he was awarded a scholarship and attended the nearby preparatory [[Collegiate School (Richmond, Virginia)|Collegiate School]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/30/arts/television/30itzk.html|title=With 'The Cleveland Show,' Mike Henry Spins Off Into Uncharted Cartoon Territory|last=Itzkoff|first=Dave|date=2009-08-27|work=The New York Times|access-date=2018-05-01|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} Henry graduated from [[Washington and Lee University]] (1988) where he earned his B.A. in history and served as class president his sophomore-senior years. Although interested in comedy, Mike never believed he could make a career of it so instead opted for more “business stuff.”{{Cite news|url=http://panthernow.com/2014/10/24/family-guy-voice-actor-visits-university/|title='Family Guy' voice actor visits University - PantherNOW|date=2014-10-24|work=PantherNOW|access-date=2018-05-01|language=en-US}} At the age of 24, after a brief career in advertising, Henry moved to [[California]] to pursue acting. There he began taking classes at the [http://www.groundlings.com/ Groundlings Theater] and performing stand-up comedy.{{Cite news|url=https://www.backstage.com/interview/playing-in-cleveland/|title=Playing in 'Cleveland'|work=Backstage.com|access-date=2018-05-02}} After three years in LA, Mike returned to Virginia to shoot short comedy films that he wrote and acted in.{{Cite web|url=https://www.styleweekly.com/richmond/welcome-back-cleveland/Content?oid=1377329|title=Welcome Back, Cleveland|website=Style Weekly|language=en|access-date=2018-05-02}} During that time, Mike often acted in his brother Patrick’s student films at the [[Rhode Island School of Design]]. It was there that he was introduced to his brother’s college roommate, [[Seth MacFarlane]]. The two quickly became friends. "We immediately hit it off and cracked each other up and kept in touch," Henry says. Henry later moved to [[New York City]] where he acted in commercials, studied improvisation at the [[Upright Citizens Brigade Theatre|Upright Citizens Brigade Theater]]{{Cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/person/mike-henry-vi?filter-options=tv|title=Mike Henry (VI)|website=Metacritic|access-date=2018-05-02}} and wrote, produced, starred-in and co-directed (with his brother Patrick) comedy shorts for [[Lorne Michaels|Lorne Michaels’]] [[Burly Bear Network]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.styleweekly.com/richmond/voice-of-the-people/Content?oid=1367039|title=Voice of the People|last=Burruss|first=Mary|website=Style Weekly|language=en|access-date=2018-05-10}} ==Career== ===''Family Guy''=== Henry’s break came in 1998, when MacFarlane contacted him about being part of a new show called ''Family Guy.'' Mike agreed and joined the project as a writer and voice actor. Henry has stated that the inspiration for Cleveland's voice was based on “this guy that [he] had once played basketball with.”{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=tRBOx3f_ZRs|title=Mike Henry: The Origins of Cleveland and Herbert|accessdate=2009-04-16}} During the show's first four seasons, he was credited as a guest star, but beginning with [[Family Guy (season 5)|season five]]'s "[[Prick Up Your Ears (Family Guy)|Prick Up Your Ears]]" he has been credited as a main cast member.{{cite news|title=Mike Henry of "Family Guy" talks voices, gags and instinct |date=September 11, 2008 |work=[[Campus Times]] |url=http://www.campustimes.org/mike-henry-of-family-guy-talks-voices-gags-and-instinct-1.743902 |accessdate=September 8, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091016192410/http://www.campustimes.org/mike-henry-of-family-guy-talks-voices-gags-and-instinct-1.743902 |archivedate=October 16, 2009 }} Since its debut on January 31, 1999, [[List of Family Guy episodes|306 episodes]] of ''Family Guy'' have been broadcast with Mike having credits in nearly all of them.{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1396611/|title=Mike Henry|website=IMDb|access-date=2018-05-02}} Two episodes into the second season, ''Family Guy'' was taken off the network's permanent schedule and shown irregularly thereafter. The show returned in March 2000 to finish airing the second season which contained 21 episodes; all the cast came back for the series return. During its second season, Fox publicly announced that the show had been cancelled.{{cite news|url=http://archive.boston.com/ae/tv/articles/2005/04/30/family_guy_returns_just_as_funny_as_ever/|title=''Family Guy'' Returns, Just As Funny As Ever|last=Gilbert|first=Matthew|date=April 30, 2005|work=Boston.com|accessdate=August 24, 2009}} Despite the announced cancellation, in 2003 Fox decided to make the third season.{{cite news|url=https://www.usatoday.com/life/television/news/2003-11-18-family-guy_x.htm|title=''Family Guy'' may return|last1=Levin|first1=Gary|date=November 18, 2003|work=USAtoday.com|accessdate=September 27, 2009}} During the third season, Fox announced that the show was canceled for good.{{cite web |url=http://familyguy.tktv.net/news.html |title=Family Guy has finally been officially canceled by Fox |work=TKtv |date=May 16, 2002 |accessdate=August 24, 2009}}{{cite news |url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A03E3D61E31F931A35756C0A9639C8B63 |title=Canceled and Resurrected, on the Air and Onstage |work=[[The New York Times]] |first=Jesse |last=McKinley |date=May 2, 2005 |accessdate=August 24, 2009}} Soon after ''Family Guy'' was cancelled, Henry and his brother created the popular web series ''[[Kicked in the Nuts]]'', a spoof of hidden camera shows. ''Family Guy'' was renewed again in 2005 for its fourth season due to strong DVD sales and its [[Broadcast syndication|syndication]] on basic cable networks.{{cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/2005/apr/13/business/fi-family13|title=Fox Reuniting Itself with ''Family Guy''|last=James|first=Meg|date=April 13, 2005|newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]]|accessdate=September 3, 2009}}{{cite news|title=Yet another ''Family'' reunion |newspaper=Chicago Sun-Times |first=Phil |last=Rosenthal |page=53 |date=November 20, 2003 |accessdate=September 3, 2009}} Once again Henry and the rest of the cast came back for their voice works. In October 2017, Family Guy was renewed for its 16th season.{{Cite news|url=https://heavy.com/entertainment/2017/05/family-guy-renewed-cancelled-will-return-season-16-2017-spoilers/|title=‘Family Guy’ Renewed or Cancelled: Is it Coming Back for Season 16?|last=Levine|first=Daniel S.|date=2017-05-22|work=Heavy.com|access-date=2018-05-02|language=en-US}} [[File:Michael Henry.jpg|thumb|Mike Henry 2018]] ===''The Cleveland Show''=== On September 27th 2009, ''[[The Cleveland Show]]'' premiered on Fox.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news.aspx?id=20090615fox01|title=FOX Announces Fall Premiere Dates For The 2009–2010 Season|date=June 15, 2009|work=The Futon Critic|accessdate=August 23, 2009}} The project was created and executive produced by Henry, [[Seth MacFarlane]], and ''[[American Dad!]]'' [[show runner]] [[Rich Appel]]. The show focused on the ''Family Guy'' character [[Cleveland Brown]]. Cleveland referenced the spinoff at the end of the Family Guy episode, "[[Baby Not on Board]]".{{cite episode|title=Baby Not On Board|series=Family Guy|network=Fox|season=7|number=4|episodelink=Baby Not on Board|serieslink=Family Guy|airdate=November 2, 2008}} The first season consisted of 22 episodes and was picked up by Fox for a second 13 episode season. The announcement was made on May 3, 2009 before the first season even premiered.{{cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/cleveland-rocks-fox-83327|title='Cleveland' rocks at Fox|last=|first=|date=|work=|access-date=|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120703141634/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/h/content_display/news/e3id8ce138992a53121b4b8137dc51ea285|archivedate=2012-07-03|deadurl=yes|df=}} Due to strong ratings, Fox picked up an additional nine season 2 episodes, bringing the total episode count of the show to 44. The show was renewed for a third and fourth season on May 9, 2011.{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefutoncritic.com/news/2010/06/10/fox-picks-up-third-season-of-the-cleveland-show/20100610fox01/|title=Breaking News - FOX Picks Up Third Season of "The Cleveland Show" {{!}} TheFutonCritic.com|website=www.thefutoncritic.com|access-date=2018-05-03}} The series was canceled after its fourth season on May 19, 2013{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/24-returns-fox-fall-article-1.1342450?pgno=1|title=Fox announces 2013-14 fall schedule, which includes return of Kiefer Sutherland's '24' - NY Daily News|last=Hinckley|first=David|work=nydailynews.com|access-date=2018-05-03|language=en-US}} but reruns continue to air on [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]] and on [[Cartoon Network|Cartoon Network's]] [[Adult Swim]] in the United States and on [[MuchMusic]] in Canada. The series ran for a total of [[List of The Cleveland Show episodes|4 seasons and 88 episodes.]]{{cite web|url=http://www.foxflash.com/div.php/main/page?aID=1z2z2z252z1z2|title=Fox Primetime – The Cleveland Show – Fact Sheet|work=Fox Flash|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100117131748/http://foxflash.com/div.php/main/page?aID=1z2z2z252z1z2|archivedate=January 17, 2010|deadurl=yes|accessdate=August 29, 2009|df=}} ==Personal life== Henry is married to Sara Voelker Henry and has two children, a son, Jack (b. October 2003) and a daughter, Josie (b. September 2007). They currently reside in Richmond, VA.{{cn|date=July 2018}} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Notes |- | rowspan="1"|2005 | ''[[Stewie Griffin: The Untold Story]]'' | [[Cleveland Brown]] / [[Herbert (Family Guy)|Herbert]] (voice) | Direct-to-DVD |- | rowspan="1"|2012 | ''[[Ted (film)|Ted]]'' | Southern Newscaster | Cameo |- | rowspan="1"|2014 | ''[[A Million Ways to Die in the West]]'' | Cowboy | Cameo |} ===Television=== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Year ! Title ! Role ! Notes |- | rowspan="1"|2006 | ''[[Family Guy Video Game!]]'' | [[Cleveland Brown]] / [[Herbert (Family Guy)|Herbert]] / Various Voices | |- | rowspan="1"|2012 | ''[[Family Guy: Back to the Multiverse]]'' | Cleveland Brown / Herbert / Various Voices | |- | rowspan=1|2014 | ''[[Family Guy: The Quest for Stuff]]'' | Cleveland Brown / Herbert / Various voices | |} ==References== '''Notes''' {{reflist}} ==External links== * [https://www.imdb.com/name/nm1396611/ Mike Henry on IMDB] * [https://twitter.com/mikehenrybro?lang=en Mike Henry on Twitter] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Henry, Mike}} [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Family Guy]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Primetime Emmy Award winners]] [[Category:The Cleveland Show]] [[Category:20th-century American comedians]] [[Category:20th-century American male actors]] [[Category:20th-century American singers]] [[Category:20th-century American writers]] [[Category:American stand-up comedians]] [[Category:American television producers]] [[Category:American male writers]] [[Category:American male singers]] [[Category:American male voice actors]] [[Category:American male comedians]] [[Category:American male screenwriters]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:American male film actors]] [[Category:American male television actors]] [[Category:Male actors from Richmond, Virginia]] [[Category:Washington and Lee University alumni]]
